awd_titl_txt: Indigenous Evaluation Framework:  Research and Capacity Building
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the challenges facing the evaluation profession is how to responsively and ethically design and conduct technically sound and systematic evaluations of programs and projects whose aims are to serve indigenous people in cultures with non-Western traditions and who are strongly tied to traditional ways of life.  This three-year mixed methods research project investigates the effectiveness and impact of the Indigenous Evaluation Framework (IEF) and its ancillary training activities and materials in addressing issues raised by efforts to design and conduct culturally responsive evaluations in tribal communities.  

The research and development project integrates a pre-post quasi-experimental design with an ethnographic qualitative research design to examine two overarching research questions:  (1) To what extent does an Indigenous Evaluation Framework (IEF) provide a model for the evaluation of STEM programs that is responsive to the unique educational and cultural environments of tribally and federally chartered colleges and universities (TCUs) and tribal communities?  (2)  To what extent does using the essential elements of the IEF result in an evaluation design that (a) is integrated into the tribal/community setting; (b) assesses the contributions of the program or project in meeting funder and community defined elements of success and desired outcomes: and (c) forms a strong basis for stakeholder use of evaluation findings for both formative improvements and a summative assessment?  In addition, the on-going investigation examines and informs the revision of the IEF and the training efforts and materials associated with the conceptualization and implementation of the IEF.  This study by the nation's 37 American Indian tribally and federally chartered colleges and universities, which collectively are the American Indian Higher Education Consortium (AIHEC), examines the effectiveness and usefulness of the IEF to respond to both non-Western cultural traditions and social science methodologies and theories that are steeped in Western scientific traditions.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
NSF Award 1337347-- AIHEC Indigenous Evaluation Framework:  Research and Capacity Building

Project Outcomes Report

The AIHEC Indigenous Evaluation Framework (IEF) was successfully tested at two tribal colleges (TCUs). The research was done to learn how the IEF worked in different community settings and how it could best be applied. Staff and faculty at the colleges were trained in a 1½ day workshop. After the workshop, the colleges applied the IEF. The training at the TCU sites demonstrated that the IEF can serve as a blueprint for curriculum and academic program development and a model for student assessment, college-wide strategic and assessment planning, as well as for evaluation. Rooting evaluation in Indigenous values and using cultural metaphors to replace the traditional logic model engages TCU faculty and staff with cultural experts. Other major lessons learned were:

The IEF model and core values were confirmed. In each of the research sites, the workshop participants confirmed that the Indigenous ways of knowing and the four core values that underlie the IEF were compatible with their own tribal values. They found the IEF to be a useful model that would work in their local context.

The IEF model is flexible. The colleges used the IEF to design curriculum, develop student assessment protocols, and work through a strategic plan.

Time was a precious commodity. Although the IEF training workshops at each of the research sites were shortened to 1 1/2 days, it was difficult for busy administrators, staff, and faculty to fit training time into their schedules. To build capacity, a different training model is needed. AIHEC is considering using a modular online approach with a syllabus that will be available on AIHEC’s website.

Community engagement is a long-term commitment. Although the AIHEC model offers commonly held views on Indigenous ways of knowing and core values, it allows space for communities to investigate their own ways of expressing tribal epistemologies and linking their individual expression of local values to evaluation practice. In two communities, this process is underway; however, it requires a thoughtful and comprehensive progression including engaging elders and cultural experts, identifying underpinnings of a cultural framework, building the framework based on local values, and interpreting how these should influence evaluation practice.

The major outcome of the research is the revision of the original IEF to reflect the research findings. The revised IEF is available on the AIHEC website at Pages - Document Collections (aihec.org). The revised manual chapters include the following.

The Foundations of Indigenous Evaluation:

  • Weaving the Basket—The Power of Metaphor
  • Honoring Indigenous Ways of Knowing
  • Respecting Core Values
  • Community engagement—Evaluation by and for Indigenous peoples
  • Reframing Evaluation

Designing an Indigenous Evaluation

  • Creating the Evaluation Story
  • Evaluation Design—Envisioning the Process

Implementing an Indigenous Evaluation

  • Collecting Information to Tell the Story
  • Data Analysis and Interpretation—Creating Meaning

Celebrating our Learning

  • Celebrating and Using Our Learning
  • Using Evaluation to Improve Programs
  • Evaluation through an Indigenous Lens

Continuing the Dialogue 

  • Working with External Evaluators
  • Working with Funders

 Useful Resources

The research demonstrated that the IEF was a viable approach to broadening the interpretation of evaluation practice to include an approach that is molded to fit within an Indigenous cultural setting.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2021
Modified by: Carrie L Billy
